course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Organic Chemistry I
course.description: This is the first part of the organic chemistry course series designed for students taking a major/minor in chemistry/life science under the four-year degree. Topics covered include: structure and bonding; regio-, geometric, and stereoisomerism; polar and radical reactions of alkenes and alkynes; substitution and elimination reactions; synthesis and reactions of alcohols and epoxides.

reviews.author: 石頭
reviews.title: DO BELIEVE THE COMMENTS(not the good ones, its a trap！ )
reviews.comment_content:
before mid term it was normal stuff like everyone expected, wont say it again as it is already in other comments.

after mid term, its like hell.

like 60 reactions with specific catalyst/reagent/solvent taught in a month

for bcb students, you have to choose analytical or organic chem as your major requirement,  DO NOT choose this course

you will regret

for bcb who choose this course
be happy
this will be the last required chem in your UG
reviews.comment_teaching:
I attended all lectures before mid term, but once only afterwards.

i think only NDS can understand his language fully and i cant really understand him much even as a local.

He talks real fast and skipping everything important, and spend plenty of time talking about shit which you wont understand if you dont understand those important concepts, and end up by saying this wont be in the exam.

i think the only use of the notes are the questions and exercises, which you can solve if you understand the mechanism

He said there wont be any lecture videos(its a 0930 class) but actually he recorded it and sent it to us 2 days before the exam,  which is definitely not fucking helpful.(probably someone asked him to send them out, the only explaination is the person never attended his lectures, i believe he wont watch the second after finishing one)
reviews.comment_grading:
actually i worte this right after the final so i dont know yet.

the final is 3 hrs and half of the class left at 2hr, other half sleeping or scratching reactions from the bottom of their memory.
hand full of them looked like they have taken drugs  and addicted to chemistry already.
i see the future .

40%mid term
60%final

the mean of the final is about 40%, making me wonder "why this course/ professor is not fired yet?"

previous statistics show if you get overall 50% you probably get a B or so

actually its not about the grades, when the mean has failed i really think UST should think about deleting the course/ change the material/ change the instructor, students cant learn much from the course, it felt like DSE style of learning to me.
i got a B , and the mean has failed as expected,
good luck
reviews.comment_workload:
nothing to talk about mid term, just normal.
if you want to get a decent grade for final, I STRRRRONGly advise you to have one whole week for revision.

I didnt give a shit to the course after midterm and i found myself miserable with the god damn lecture notes, and i have 3 days left before exam.

3 whole days (like 10hrs a day) for me to understand all the chapters(of course inclucing time for me to search for the appropriate way to lean) and few hours to do little examples, i cant do the inhumane last 30 marks which you have to synthesize something through dozens of reactions.

actually i borrowed the old version text book(new one is only for 2HR reservation)  and and i saw there were a few more left which i think explains why the mean for the finals had failed.

youtube is the savior, learnt everything about Sn1,2 and E1,2 from there. and maybe i should learn everything from there in the first place.

P.S. i noticed some comments with quite good ratings
THOSE ARE ILLUSIONS
as they were written right after the mid term,not the finals, be careful.

reviews.author: shaolinmonk
reviews.title: Good cure for insomnia
reviews.comment_content: Same as other posts. Way too much useless things condensed into a semester. No interesting content at all.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Tong's voice has been able to cure my insomnia, every class I am able to fall asleep within minutes. Teaching is done way too fast and without enough explanation. No lecture video is provided but it would be useless anyways.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 55%
Final 45%

Midterm relatively alright compared to final. Even though final is take home it is impossible to finish. Basically just pages and pages of reactions and mechanism questions.
Almost impossible to get good grade if you have other rigourous courses and you want to have a life.
reviews.comment_workload: Lectures are kinda like introduction only, you spend way too much time outside of class watching videos and self-reading to learn the material. Impossible to complete all the recommended questions if you are studying hard for other courses too.

reviews.title: Terrible course, course of death, and a hostile trash talking instructor

reviews.comment_grading:
Nothing out of normal, a disaster for me, he goes out of his way to personally fuck my grades over as I asked him to provide better recording for revision, and he blames me for not remembering everything within the lecture, if you got a bad grade, don't worry it isn't your fault, it is this course and the professor, and did I mentioned how he fuck the SEN over in final? reviews.author: Sonic12
reviews.title: Miserable and Irresponsible Course
reviews.comment_content:
LT-1:  Introduction to Organic Chemistry, Structure
LT-2:   Atomic Bonding
LT-3/4: Polar Covalent Bonds, Lewis Acids and bases
LT-5: Alkanes and their stereochemistry
LT-6: Cycloalkanes and their stereochemistry
LT-7/8: Stereochemistry at tetrahedral centers
LT-9/10: Overview of organic reaction
LT-11/12: Alkenes—structure and reactivity
---------------------Midterm exam -------------------------
LT-14/15: Alkenes—reaction and synthesis
LT-16/17: Alkyne—Introduction to Organic Synthesis
LT-18: Organic Halides
LT-19/20: Reactions of Alkyl halides
LT-21/22: Alcohol and Phenols
LT-23/24: LT-24/25: Ethers and Epoxide, Thiol and sulfides
LT-25: Organic Synthesis
------------------------Final Exam----------------------------
Typical coverage of contents in organic chemistry I. Some say it's too excessive but that's what all organic chem courses actually are.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lot's to say about teaching. I attended all the miserable lectures so I'm pretty sure that I am qualified to criticize the teaching problem.

In a nutshell, just don't attend the lectures. The only things you need to do to prepare for the exams are self-study and suggested exercises at the end of each lecture slide.

The professor just reads off the slides and wastes time in explaining his research (which no one cares about) and other unnecessary complex reactions which are not covered in the exams.

In learning organic chemistry, a good explanation of the electron flow mechanism is a must. That's why an appropriate utilization of a whiteboard or pen is needed. However, this guy just points out the reaction mechanisms by his laser pointer, and turns out no one understands it.

I know the "professor" Rongbiao Tong took charge of this course for a long time. However, considering a tone of bad reviews on ust space and witnessing that there's no improvement in his teaching, there can be only two possible conclusions.

He does not willing to improve his teaching after all these years because of his stubbornness or he just sucks at teaching.

A change in instructor to other faculty is required.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm and Final exams, the percentage for each exam is not announced even at the end of the course.

Midterm
low: 31, mean: 72.9, high: 115.5, std: 18.8
me: 97/120

Final
low: 16, mean: 77.45, high: 175, std: 41.8
me: 135/180

Overall: A

Some say the grading is good but hey, just do the math. Even though I got an A grade if you see the std for exams, especially the final exam, distinction for students' performance is shit.

A high std such as 41.8 means the students' performance is severely divided into two groups, ones who are good at org chem and the others who are not familiar with org chem.

Which in turn, could mean high performers already know a lot about org chem even before they take this course, and low performers haven't learned anything about organic chemistry through this course.

Overall, irresponsible teaching and irresponsible grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only midterm and final exams. But considering the lectures do not provide you with any help for preparing for the exams, the workload could be quite high.

If you are already familiar with organic chemistry that's fine, but if you are a newcomer, just like most of the students who attend this course, use youtube lecture videos.

The difficulty of exams is almost similar to organic chem olympiads so brace yourself and prepare as much as you can to survive this course.

Good Luck

reviews.author: 綿綿頭上飛花
reviews.title: RIDICIOUS COURSE
reviews.comment_content:
Unacceptable length of content. Before the midterm was actually still tolerable -- if you study the notes with the aid of youtube each week. After midterm, it becomes a whole new world which is like hell. With unlimited reactions for you to rememorize. And not to mention he put the most bulky part towards the end of the semester... Turns out skipping through 8x ppt page in a 80 mins zoom lecture due to the limited teaching week. My only question during the zoom classes: WHY ON THE EARTH CAN'T YOU CUT THE SYLLABUS??????????  ITS RIDICIOUS.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Don't expect that he can teach you anything. I basically self-studied with the aid of youtube. All he do during zoom lecture is pointing around the molecules. He can teach Stereochemistry (S/R configuration) by just pointing around the molecule. What can you expect????

Start your youtube self-study journey as early as possible. The usage of his lecture is actually informing me which slides are not required. He actually did put labels on not required slide at first. But stopped at I think LT19. Beware of that, as he has many not required slide mixed into his ppt.  

And towards the end of the semester, as he cannot finish the unreasonable length of ppt, he just start to skip (self-learning again). The last 4 ppt had more than 80 pages, he had to rush 1 of these per lecture. 80 mins with more than 80 pages. Anyone with a bit of math knowledge will know the outcome :)

Midterm: 40%
With an average of 75.4 marks. s.d. unknown

Final:60%
No statistic can be given yet coz I wrote this review after the exam.

reviews.comment_grading:
Starting from 2019, Prof lowers the difficulty of the course. It is no longer a challenging course for bcb and chem major students. So students can choose this course if you don't want to calculate anything.
But the first thing is that you must be diligent enough to do more exercise in order to get good grade.

Midterm is very easy. You must be able to know how to answer all the question if you study hard enough.
He is quite lenient in midterm.
But because final is an open book take home exam, final exam is very difficult, which is impossible to complete in 4 hrs.

Again think carefully before choosing this course.
But I think it is not a bad grade course anymore.
Study hard and you must get a good grade as prof lowers the difficulty already. It is now an alternative of an chem.

My score:
Midterm: 110/120 (55%)
Final: 131.5/160 (45%)
Overall: 87%
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is extremely high.
But there is almost no calculation in this course, which is a good thing for students who are bad in Maths.
Before midterm it is already very demanding, as there are 10 chapters, with each chapters have lots of things to memorise and learn, especially cyclohexane,
R&S configuration.......
After midterm it is crazy, there are tonnes of chemical reactions needed to memorise. Although it is open book exam, you won't have enough time to find the appropriate reaction in the notes.
You need to spend more than 10 days before each exam for revision. But I think it really worths.

reviews.author: ym7135
reviews.title: I apologize in advance for the loss of your sanity if you have to take this
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term:
Bonding, Lewis Acid and Bases, Alkanes, Cycloalkanes, isomerism, Alkene structure, organic reaction principals.

After mid-term:
Alkenes, Alkynes, Organohalides, Alcohols, phenols, Ethers, Epoxide, Thiol, Sulphides

So you may be looking at all this and wondering - I know some organic chemistry from highschool, this shouldn't be tooo hard, or how hard can this be?? Well I was just as naive as you, but in reality this course starts of really easy and just skyrockets, nothing makes any sense after the 4th or 5th chapter, and after the mid term you have to remember over 60 different reaction mechanisms, each of which has their unique condition and the mechanism drawings are too complicated, while almost all the reactions look the same. Whats worse is that you don't even understand the purpose of these reagents - like why this temperature, why this metal, why can't another metal be used? and even for the same reaction there may be 3 or 4 different conditions for them. Be expected to be able to recall some 500 pages of textbook which all look the same.

There was far too much content for such a short amount of time, and issue is none of it makes sense, you are only memorising them for exams thats it. This is made worse with the "teaching" that goes with it, the professor is just like a museum exhibit person - 'this is the reaction that converts ... to ....' points at it for a few seconds and moves on, without actually elaborating??  yet we need to know how to draw it. The textbook itself has sooo much details (the textbook is the lifesaver) yet the ppts had more details which he just skims through. He spends so much time describing his own lab research, which nobody is actually interested in, and ends up saying 'this is not needed for exams'. While there is a bunch of stuff which are just randomly there, do we need it or not? most of the ppt is actually just copied and pasted from the textbook, however excluding the important parts which actually attempt to explain it.

And then comes exams - after you gone mad from trying to remember the content, he creates these super hard exam which looks nothing like what you studied. Like in the mid-term he expected us to recall the structure of some organic molecules from the top of our heads ?? like we were never told to memorize this? and the finals was just much worse - the last few questions we had to design this 14-15 step pathway - I can't even get a lot of the reaction mechanisms right and you expect us to derive 14-15 step mechanism?
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am going to be objective here rather than straight up dissing (trust me soooo many have done so already), lets analyse the facts!

1) The mean of the mid-term and finals has failed (below 50%)
2) Out of over 200 people in the class, the attendance is less than 20 (take a hint)
3) Lecture notes are unclear and has too much irrelevant stuff that nobody cares about. While the important parts lack detail and are exactly copied and pasted from the textbook.
4) A majority of students solely use the textbook or youtube videos for revision, and this is one of the most well known 'self-taught' course
5) Most students don't actually understand the content after the lecture (I mean those that attend) - many have stated that it is partially because of his dull and mundane teaching style.
6) At the end of the course, we actually have no clue how these organic synthesis reactions occur in the lab, we only memorize so many reactions yet have no idea how this is done in the lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term - 40%, Final exam - 60%

I have to be a bit nicer here, the grading is decent - because everyone else does horribly so the mean is low (as expected). Like the mid-term mean actually failed (56/120) which I found hilarious. I have actually seen people cry after the mid-term, which is not very surprising because the exam looks like it was written in Swahili or something, absolutely nothing like what is in the textbook or the "lecture materials". While the final exam has a mean of 78/180.

The exams had some MCQs, a lot of it were short questions, but the finals had the long mechanism questions. The MCQs were okay, but the longer questions just seem unrealistic and inhumane.

The mean is around a B-, getting a 50% overall is enough for a B, 60% is about a B+, and over 65% is already an A-. The standard deviation is actually quite high for this course as some students actually do well (most likely good self-studying techniques)
reviews.comment_workload:
Mainly just preparation for mid-term and finals, however there is a lot of self-studying and revision so workload is quite high. Most of the content is not clear from the get-go so you may need to spend so long to understand. Do get the textbook though it will save your life.

Be prepared to think you finished one chapter and move to the next and then forget that entire chapter completely. And then at the end you think you studied everything and then you get to the exam to experience this huge mind blank. Enjoy~

reviews.author: chantelle98
reviews.title: WARNING: this course may be hazardous to your mental health
reviews.comment_content:
- way too much content in a short amount of time, especially after the mid term. Estimation of probably 55-60 pathways/mechanisms that needed to be learnt AND applied to complicated molecules in the exam. (PS if you have done IB HL chemistry and thought this wont be too bad, you'll be proven wrong- the HL content will probably be the easiest stuff that will be covered in this course)
-each lecture powerpoint is very lengthy- he covers a lot of content in a short amount of time-- too fast and may be difficult to take in so much all at once.
-exam content is way more difficult than the textbook, which he claims to be following for teaching this course.
-ppts sometimes include complicated pathways that arent in the textbook- ppts also lack explanation. ~85% of ppt are diagrams with no explanation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
-skims through powerpoint, lots of irrelevant info on the powerpoint that he may spend time explaining, only to tell you its not needed for the exams.
-suspected to tip off certain students about exam info. Eg: last question on the final exam was seen worked out in the scihome whiteboard before the exam. (which was a 10 mark question on synthetic pathways, the right solution having 13 steps)
-expect to be your own teacher if you take this course!! :) free youtube lectures and the textbook is your savior
reviews.comment_grading:
-mid term 40%, final 60%.
-Multiple sections within paper, ranging from simple / MCQ to (for the final) complicated 10 mark questions asking you to design the synthetic route from 1/ more starting molecules to a final, more complicated one.
-mid term mean was roughly 47%
reviews.comment_workload: - E= because you have to self study everything. we were encouraged to do textbook end of chapter questions. Exam questions are different in style so I didnt find it helpful to work on them even though I finished all in preparation for the midterm.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Tong tends to teach in a very detailed manner. He explains the concepts quite clearly. The teaching pace is moderate. Tong part teaches mostly conceptual contents in this course, which means you might wanna spend some time understanding the content rather then pure memorization.

Professor Nakamura is quite enthusiastic in teaching organic chemistry and try to make people enjoy learning it. But sometimes when he is trying to explain the examples in ppt he might go through it very quickly as he thinks its very straight forward and easy. Depending on how quickly you understand to content, this may be good or bad to you. (Since Nakamura part is mostly about organic reactions, not a lot of concept wise content. Most of it is indeed straight forward indeed)
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 40%
Final 60%
No attendance requirement

Final (at least as stated by the Prof) consists of  90% of content taught after midterm. And roughly 10% of content taught before midterm. But the truth is the content sometimes are closely related. (E.g. concept taught before midterm might help explaining the rationale which some of the organic reactions occurs in such a way.)

Midterm is a mix of short question, mcq and matching the answer. Final is somewhat similar but a lot lot more lenghty. Both midterm and final are at similar difficulty I would say. (If you remember 80% of the content and at least understands the basic concept you will get at least B+)

Midterm: 88/120 (Mean is 71 or 7x, highest 107 or 10x)
Final: 267/400  (咁大個仔第一次見400分一份卷, Mean 171.9, Low:15, High 385(不如你去教？))
Letter grade: A-

I would say the grading is quite good.

reviews.comment_content:

Luckily, many exercises could be found in the textbook which were extremely useful for us to get familiar with the chapters. Therefore, I strongly recommend u guys to get one from the bookstore and read through all content at least 2 weeks before the exam!!!

Also, students should pay more attention to the chapter about nucleophilic substitution and elimination, as this involves the most important concept.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TONG could be very obstinate at times, he DID NOT show any respect to OVERSEAS students. Because of the pandemic, ZOOM was the only way for us to learn. Even though the situation got improved later, some students still continued to rely on ZOOM during lecture time. However, not only did he ignore the messages in the chatbox, but he also forgot to adjust the camera position so none of us could see the real-time demonstration done by him.    Despite the fact that we had sent him many emails to raise our concern, he was still in a nonchalant manner   !!!

In the class, TONG just read through the PPT slides with his monotone, and everyone stayed silent. Our insomnia could definitely be cured.

  When it came nearly the end of the semester, TONG once said 'I will only benefit students who attend the f2f lecture, I know students on ZOOM can't see the laser point on the screen, so don't complain to me!'

ABSURD!
RIDICULOUS!

reviews.author: phyllissssss
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are acceptable when you listen to the lectures, but when you begin to review all the reactions just a few days before the exam, you will find this course is literally a disaster. You need to memorise mountains of organic reactions. But for the students who have learnt organic chemistry before in the high school, it is ok and even simple. But for those without the fundamental knowledge about organic chemistry and first time to learn, you need to pay lots of effort to understand the mechanism and recite all the reactions.

reviews.author: cabbi
reviews.comment_content:
before midterm it was mostly high school stuff: naming conventions/lewis structure/ calculation of degree of unsaturation/ inductive effect/acidity,basicity...

after midterm there are loads of reactions and more mechanisms, important concepts include: carbocations, regioselectivity, m's rule, sn2/sn1/e1/e2 reactions.....
reviews.comment_teaching: speaks a bit too fast and flat toned and is hard to keep up with during the lesson. the lecture videos are posted after the termination of face-to-face lessons and I still have to pause and re-listen to many parts of the video to grab what he explained..
reviews.comment_grading:
seemed fair. he mentioned giving around 20 percent of a range (including a-). I did averagely in midterm and pretty horribly in final and probably got what I deserved hh

btw the slides are really important!!!! I completely ignored the slides before midterm and was told by the ta that lots of questions in midterm actually come from the questions on the lecture slides during paper checking session...

and to really learn the course well, preview is recommended (if I  had done it!!) it was simply impossible for me to go in blank minded and catch up with him for the whole lecture
reviews.comment_workload: no assignments, only midterm and final are counted towards the final grade. however you have to spend long time understanding the mechanisms. strongly recommend saving one week for final preparation (especially if you plan to PREVIEW everything just before the exam). I spent 3 days previewing and felt like my stomach was about to explode and could vomit at any moment due to the compulsively rapid intake of information

reviews.author: cantdouni
reviews.title: This course will make you cry
reviews.comment_content:
This course has a very detailed content covering most of high school organic chemistry. the topics start off easy, giving you a false sense of security, but literally make your life miserable later. some of the topics covered include: structure and bonding,acids and bases, alkanes, cycloalkanes, alkenes, alkynes,alkyl halides, complex reaction mechanisms, alcohols and phenols, ethers and epoxides.
Basically an awful lot to cover in a short time.
reviews.comment_teaching: Horrendous, monotonous, just plain boring. The content is very complicated in itself, and his teaching style does not help in any way. it is very hard to follow what he's saying and explaining. There are no lecture videos, and trust me, you wouldn't want to watch them anyway. I literally studied most of the content myself from the book, which does a fairly decent job.

midterm is 40%:

final is 60%:
mean=75.89/180     sd=36.99

reviews.comment_workload:
since this course only has a midterm and a final, workload around that period increases by a massive amount due to all the memorisation required for the reactions and the structures.
The final is cumulative, so be prepared to give a crazy amount of time for preparation.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Almost all comments I read said that TONG teaches badly and there's no need of attending his lectures. However I think he explained things quite clearly and the teaching is ok.
As for Nakamura, it is really hard for me to get used to his accent at first. I sometimes didn't realize he was speaking English and thought he was speaking Japanese. But it is ok after you get used to his accent and strange pausing and rhythm. His lecture is more lively than professor TONG as he sometimes walk around and interact with active students. （He says funny things when no one respond, like "you don't give a sh*t?")
I usually prefer textbooks comparing to lecture notes, but the professors said that some contents on the textbooks are wrong, and the lecture notes also provide more details somehow.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: full mark 120, 40%
MCs and short questions (ranking) and a few long questions on mechanism and explanation for phenomena
Mean: 71.99     Median: 71 High: 109    Low: 35
Upper Quartile: 81 Lower Quartile: 64

Final: full mark 400, 60%
MCs, short questions (ranking), filling in products of reactions, 2 long questions for mechanism, 1 long question for organic synthesis
Mean: 170.49   Median: 157 High: 397    Low: 0
Upper Quartile: 249.75 Lower Quartile: 93.75

Me
Midterm: 84/120   FInal: 319/400
Letter Grade: A

Actually the grade I got is better than I originally expected. I thought I would get A- at most since I didn't do well in midterm but got A.
I heard that final is more difficult than midterm so I was quite fructrated when I messed up the midterm. However, final was not as difficult as I thought it would be. Don't know if it's because Nakamura teach the course for the first time, his final questions are way more easier than those from pastpapers of TONG. Nakamura said the summary slides after each lecture slides are important and "the exam will be exactly like that", and the part for filling in products is indeed exactly the same, which is quite surprising. The questions for mechanism can also be found on slides, but unfortunately I didn't managed to remember those two mechanisms. I also didn't know how to do the synthesis, but TAs are very kind and gave me part of the marks.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite high in my opinion. The contents are manageable for midterm, but in final there are many reactions to memorize. More importantly, long questions of organic synthesis definitely require lots of practice. (It is really lucky for me that there is only 1 long quetion of synthesis this year and the majority is blank-filling of products, otherwise I will die) (But don't know if it is still like this next year) I didn't spare time for the optional after-class exercise, but I think it would be helpful if you spend time doing it. Try to memorize some of the contents daily, so you won't be too miserable when preparing for the final exam.

The grading of midterm is strict. You get marks only when you got it all correct in some questions.
Lecture video will be provided just before a few days of final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: No Assignment but quite lots of things got to remember.

reviews.author: hfchanae
reviews.comment_content: The content was mainly about some basic properties of organic compounds and function groups, such as alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, etc. Many synthesis would be covered in the final part.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very unfluent and hardly understandable English. The time slot was bad (4:30pm-5:50pm). Therefore, very few people is willing to attend the class. For me, mostly was based on self-study.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was quite good, 5 marks margin for each sub grade. Mean is around 50, which would get B-. At least 70% to get A range.

40% Midterm
60% Final

Both midterm and final exam would consist of MC, True or False, Mechanism, Reaction and Synthesis.

Synthesis is the most important to define whether u can get an A range or not. Other part are easy to handle if you have good memories from the notes and textbooks. MC are simply basic concepts.
reviews.comment_workload: Light if u only want to pass. A lot of effort must be paid if you want to achieve higher course grade. It is because there is still a lot of functional group and their reaction to remember.

reviews.author: Leo Han
reviews.title: Organic Chem I (good grade??)
reviews.comment_content: Basically talked about the structures and properties of different functional groups. The content is easies before midterm, mainly including few concepts such as bonding theory and acid and base. After midterm, more specific reactions and mechanisms are covered, which also needs a lot of time to remember.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Tong's teaching sometimes could be boring, especially discussing the reactions, but generally is not too bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
40% midterm
60% final
(The grade is good actually. 20% A range in total and nearly 5% A+. One of the best courses I've ever had.)
The midterm is easy, however, the final is a little bit tricky, requires many mechanisms and reactions.
reviews.comment_workload: Only midterm and final means you have to spend quite a lot of time on reviewing be exams. It's better to remember those reactions after lectures, or it will be nightmare in the study break.

reviews.author: JustyAbbie
reviews.comment_content:
Pre-midterm:
主要係basic organic chemistry需要知嘅野，例如：structure and bonding, stereochemistry, acidity, etc.

Post-midterm:
(1) Reactionssssss：
差唔多大部分都要記晒：alkene, alkyne, halide, alcohol, epoxide, ether, 夾埋大約40個

reviews.comment_teaching:
上堂其實都幾悶，一來唔係好聽得明佢嘅口音；二來去到post-midterm嘅課題，佢會加勁多textbook以外嘅reactions入去混淆視聽（包括好多佢自己lab嘅research）。通常都啲人都會走堂，或者入去唔小心瞓著咗，有聽書嘅都未必聽得明。

佢final前有announcement講大概考D咩，溫習範圍有比較清晰（起碼知道有邊D reactions/ mechanisms較重要）。但佢第一句係："I have received many email inquiries on the topics covered in the final exam. Herein, I give an overview to all students for the sake of fairness."，所以想知多啲應該send下email去問穩陣啲。

reviews.author: fierce_bad_girl
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
He has the most laughably Chinese accent I've heard, and it's monotonous, dreary and sounds like he has a mouthful of shit.
Good luck trying not to drop dead in class.
Half the class skived off, even when he sent out notices that were like "I'll be talking about important shit tomorrow/the exam/if you don't come I'll flunk your ass" so yeah, you can probably guess how terrible he is
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair, I suppose. I hear you can get another five or ten marks on your midterm and/or final if you're (a) somewhat hot and (b) female, which most of us at UST unfortunately aren't.
Lucky souls who fit into (a) and (b), go find him in his office on a quiet day and reap those benefits
reviews.comment_workload: Ambivalent. What do you say about a course which you can choose to (a) not work and flunk the fuck out of or (b) eat the book, memorize your ass off and get a mediocre grade?

reviews.author: Mike Lam
reviews.comment_content:
To me, the content is just right, not too many, and not too few.
  The first part is the basic things, which includes orbitals, drawing structures, orbital hybridization, formation of bonds, molecular shape and bond polarity. Then comes acid and bases, with detailed discussion on the factors affecting acid strength. After that would be alkanes and cycloalkanes, in which their limited amount of reactions are mentioned. Conformations of both cyclo- and aliphatic alkanes are discussed, which is followed by stereochemistry. A brief discussion on the various types of reaction and how to draw reaction mechanisms is taught before midterm.
  After midterm is comes the physical chemistry of reactions, including kinetics and energetics. Then, various functional groups and their typical reactions are discussed. Functional groups mentioned include alkenes, alkynes, alkyl halides, alcohols, epoxides, ethers, thiols and sulfides. An in depth discussion on SN2, SN1, E2 E1 and E1cb mechanisms is inserted after the alkyl halides.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite good. The instructor is from mainland, so he speaks with an accent, but his english is still quite clear and understandable. Pace not too fast. At the start of every powerpoint is a summary of the last powerpoint and a revision question, which facilitates consolidation of knowledge of the past powerpoint. Very patient on answering questions, often a long queue would appear after class, waiting to ask questions. It is not rare to take half an hour for the queue to disappear.
reviews.comment_grading: I am not sure about the others, but I got an A+ with an overall 95+%. Midterm 40%, Final 60%. According to announcement, overall 50% is B-, then each 5% more (less) is a subgrade higher (lower, resp.). Statistics before paper checking for final shows that most people got B-, followed by B. Updated statistics not given, but is estimated to be similar.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. At the first few lessons, assignments are assigned, but as declared in the first lesson, these assignments are neither collected nor graded. Studying for exams is quite useful, especially for final. However, he focus on testing our understanding rather than memory, so not much to memorize except for the reactions and the reagents used. As a result, the overall workload is very light.

reviews.author: EdogawaC
reviews.title: Lots of reactions, not enough time to learn them all
reviews.comment_content: A lot of new knowledge on organic reactions, mechanisms, syntheses, but not enough time to master them. Course is taught too fast and too many things crammed into one semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof teaches fast, talks too fast, doesn't update pdf with in-class questions, so if you can't follow in class, well...
reviews.comment_grading: Surprisingly not too bad grade, a little above 70% was enough for A-. If do enough practices from textbook, getting a high grade should be achievable.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework, no quizzes, have mid term and final, both accounting to 50 % of final grade. my advice is to work hard for mid term, since there are a lot fewer reactions learnt compared with final.

reviews.author: yuu
reviews.comment_content: The course give me a glance how organic chemistry looks like. If you try to clear the concepts after every lesson, it can be easier when it comes to midterm and final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor's accent was relatively hard for me to understand what he was talking about. I skip nearly all the lessons after midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm - 40%
Final - 60%

I got ~60% for the whole course and I got a B+.
It is better to get high marks in midterm as final exam is really difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: No hand-in assignments. Students can do the suggested exercises listed on the last page of the powerpoint.

reviews.author: qorhvk
reviews.comment_content: Overall useful. Content before midterm was fairly easy (I mean easier than what I heard of). Final exam portion was difficult, mainly due to mechanisms which require a great amount of time to memorize it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor's English was not the worst, but sometimes it was hard to understand due to his Chinese accents. His voice was monotonic, easily falling into sleep.
reviews.comment_grading: 40% midterm and 60% final. MCQ, short questions and long questions are included. Final is extremely hard. You have to memorize all mechanisms and deduce how one particular compound ends up with a different compound.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that much. It's purely exam based. Depends on how well you can memorize.

reviews.author: fghfdhfh
reviews.comment_content: pretty okay.  good basic coverage. fully understood everything and important basis to come back to for further courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: i liked his style. something about his voice makes it very interesting to listen to and i sometimes fantasize of soothing into his lecturing room. pretty jenggg.
reviews.comment_grading: grading was fair and consistent with the peers.
reviews.comment_workload: medium workload and revision was easy but lengthy. i liked that i could balance my time off with his lecture courses and often read them on the bus back home. i met a random guy.

reviews.author: diudiu
reviews.title: Don't go to the lectures, it's not worth it
reviews.comment_content: The ABCs of organic chemistry. Covers all the things you'll need in higher level orgo - naming, stereochemistry, functional groups, thermodynamics, some fundamental reaction mechanisms, and then some more reaction mechanisms.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It only took me one lecture to decide not to go in all subsequent lectures. His English is atrocious and he wasn't exactly too competent in explaining stuff. The powerpoint slides were pretty information-heavy, and I appreciate the effort to put in his own lab's work as examples, but his delivery ultimately made them more confusing than inspiring.

Don't rely on him to learn anything. Just read the textbook and do some exercises yourself and you'll be fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tong was extremely lenient with his grading if you do well enough. This probably had something to do with the exquisitely low average score though (it's in the low 40s). The average grade was on par with the University average at B-, but once you get to A range (~20%, or 30 people) he's impossibly nice. 60% overall is enough to score you an A-. The thresholds for A and A+ were 66% and 73.7% respectively. 12 (!!) people got A+.

My grade: 98/120 midterm; 126/180 final; overall 74.7%, A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment or attendance requirements whatsoever. You do have to put in the effort after the midterms though, since memorising all the subtle details of organic reactions is no easy task. It's not just memorising though, you will actually have to apply them in the final exam, as a significant part of the exam would be devoted to coming with reaction mechanisms and synthetic pathways. You either need to (1) practice a lot; or (2) be very creative.

I don't think I'm particularly creative, so I had to cram a lot of exercises instead; luckily the instructor did list out selected questions for practice at the end of each chapter, that was pretty helpful.

reviews.author: Milktea
reviews.title: LEAVE if you are a BCB student
reviews.comment_content:
If you are a BCB student or a LIFS student who unfortunately got this course during prereg, PLEASE LEAVE and check if you can study analytical chemistry. If you, unfortunately, have to study this course, I will warn you right now, the road ahead is a cycle of cluelessness that requires you to be efficient in self directed learning.

No matter if you are a BCB student or a CHEM student, the consensus is the same. NO ONE UNDERSTANDS THE MATERIAL. Be a good student and learn everything by yourself.

Summary of contents:
Midterm: Strength of acid and base, Stereochemistry of organic compounds, Reactivity of alkenes
Final: Reactions of alkene, alkyne, alkyl halide, SN1, SN2

Midterm content: C
Tolerable. Do not expect to learn much during class, the teaching pace is way too fast and TONG will briefly mention important concepts in a few words. The content is not hard in the sense that the materials for learning are all in PowerPoint. It is a must to learn EVERYTHING IN DETAIL via youtube.

Final content: E
Absolute HELL. Imagine DSE organic reactions but instead of 10 reactions, there are now 100+ reactions that have different reagents.

The PowerPoint includes images with extremely low resolution that includes important concepts about organic reactions between alkenes, alcohols, esters. There is little to no explanation on all the slides, so good luck with understanding the concepts, the only way to understand anything is through googling the name of the concepts. Lectures won't help either, NAKAMURA just mentions what happens in the PowerPoint "This attack this and end up like this" As you can see, "extremely useful".

If you are on a time crunch, go revise SN1 and SN2 alcohol reactions by finding youtube videos by Prof Dave explains. Don't bother with the PowerPoint for that part
reviews.comment_teaching:
TONG Rongbiao: C
His accent is tolerable, a lot better than Jia. He also speaks at a normal pace which helps a lot.  Unfortunately, he assumes that students would know the content by mentioning a few words. The good thing about this professor is that he would answer questions after lessons and he actually cares about students. His accent is tolerable and I could mostly understand what he says.

NAKAMURA, Hugh: E
I could not understand what he was saying after the second lesson. His Japanese accent makes it even worse. I also asked a few different students and came to the same conclusion. NO ONE UNDERSTANDS HIM. He also really likes to say "You don't give a sh*t?" when no one asks questions. DO YOU EXPECT ME TO RAISE MY HAND AND SAY "I DON'T UNDERSTAND ANYTHING, PLEASE TEACH AGAIN!" I got so annoyed that I did not attend any lectures after Chapter 17
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was the best thing about this course. Because all the students did not know what was going on, and the grading was curve based, it would be hard to get F.

I even heard students after the final exam say that they did not know what they were doing during the exam, the same goes for me, I did not know what I was doing.

I was 2 marks below the midterm and 6% below the mean for the final.

I ended up getting a B-, which was much better than I expected. I felt like I did not learn much from all the lectures.
reviews.comment_workload:
Many would say workload is low as there are no assignments or quizzes. There is just midterm and final.

However, it does not mean that your actual workload is low, much time is needed for studying this course. Allocate your time wisely.

I suggest doing exercises from the organic chemistry book suggested at the back of each powerpoint.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I feel like professor Tong is great at teaching the concepts and i understand him fairly well despite the slight accent. His lecture slides are comprehensive and he does give suggested questions at the end of each lecture. He even provides examples of the reactions he teaches through his own research work, showing how they piece together in an organic synthesis pathway.

I do however feel that he rushes the content a bit much, especially nearing the final examination. And although he gives suggested questions from the textbook for us to work out, it would be better if he solved a few examples to show us how its done.

reviews.author: biochemnerd
reviews.title: Don't take this course unless absolutely necessary, you will have PTSD (like me)
reviews.comment_content:
Begins with basics like drawing lewis structures, newman projections, naming, R/S stereochemistry and resonance structures. Then its about certain functional groups like alcohols, thiols, ether, epoxide, alkene, alkyne, aromatics. Its all what basic organic chemistry courses entail in most unis probably.
I have attached the file with the intro stuff.
The issue is not with that, but the amount of memorization and actual practice required to master these concepts. What I found the worst was that we begin with making C-C-O-H and are expected to master synthesizing compounds within a span of 3 months, which is INSANE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Okay, this one is tough. He's unclear and monotone = recipe for disaster when it comes to teaching us easily bored students.
Prof's accent is super hard to understand most times, unless you specifically pay attention to every word (which takes a LOT of energy). His explanations are further worsened by simple, unclear statements with terminology thrown around. There is no lecture video, which wouldn't help anyway since his
He does try to make class interesting by adding "real-life" examples or applications made by his students in the lab BUT it only confuses students further.
reviews.comment_grading:
No clue on the grading tbh. The only thing we were told were the means and SD.
Midterm (40%):
     mean= 56.39/120   sd= 18.36
Final (60%):
     mean= 167/180   sd= 36.99
The good thing was the mean was super low, yet there was a grading scheme devised even if you were within +/- sd, which I'm not sure about.
reviews.comment_workload: Even though its only midterm and final, you can only hope to get a good grade is if you are a computer who can remember a 100 reactions and their catalysts/conditions (I'm serious) in the time of ~1.5 months. If you can, well done. If you can't, then I'd suggest you make your peace with a bad grade or drop this course while you have the chance. I knew people who did well too, but I'm not sure how they managed to do that, given I worked at least 8 hrs a week on this content and still managed to almost fail.
